section.title: must/might/can't have
section.sectiontitle: Use must have + past participle to say that you believe something was certain in the past.
section.text1a: You looked tanned. You must have been somewhere sunny.
section.text2a: She isn't here. She must have left early.
section.sectiontitle2: Use may or might have + past participle to say something was a possibility in the past.
section.text3a: I can't find my wallet. I think I might have left it in that shop.
section.text4a: She may have stopped to get some petrol.

section.title: must/might/can't have
section.sectiontitle: Use can't or couldn't have + past participle to say that you believe something was not possible in the past.
section.text1a: She hasn't phoned me so she can't have got my message.
section.text2a: They couldn't have gone swimming. They didn't take any towels.
section.sectiontitle2: May / might / must / could and can't have are the same for all persons I / you / he / she / it / we / they.
section.text3a: He couldn't have seen it; he wasn't there.
section.text4a: They couldn't have seen it; they weren't there.

section.title: must/might/can't have
section.sectiontitle: May have and might have + past participle can also refer to the present or future.
section.text1a: I'll give him a call but he may have left by now.
section.text2a: By this time next year I might have moved to Brussels.
